sub_topic: Calculating the effect of changing the concentration of a common ion on the equilibrium position
message_1: How does the addition of a common ion affect the equilibrium position of a chemical reaction? Provide a practical example using the equilibrium reaction of AgCl (s) ⇌ Ag+ (aq) + Cl- (aq) and calculate the effect of adding 0.1 M NaCl on the concentration of silver ion at equilibrium given an initial concentration of 0.02 M Ag+ and 0.01 M Cl-.
message_2:
The addition of a common ion affects the equilibrium position of a chemical reaction according to Le Chatelier's principle. Le Chatelier's principle states that if a system at equilibrium is subjected to a change in concentration, temperature, or pressure, the system will adjust its equilibrium position to counteract the change.

In the case of the equilibrium reaction of AgCl (s) ⇌ Ag+ (aq) + Cl- (aq), the common ion effect can be observed when a salt containing either Ag+ or Cl- ions is added to the solution. This will shift the equilibrium position to counteract the change in concentration of the common ion.

For example, if NaCl is added to the solution, the concentration of Cl- ions will increase. According to Le Chatelier's principle, the system will shift its equilibrium position to decrease the concentration of Cl- ions. This will cause the reaction to shift to the left, favoring the formation of AgCl (s) and reducing the concentration of Ag+ ions in the solution.

To calculate the effect of adding 0.1 M NaCl on the concentration of silver ion at equilibrium, we can use the solubility product constant (Ksp) expression for the reaction:

Ksp = [Ag+] [Cl-]

The Ksp value for AgCl is 1.8 x 10^-10.

Initially, the concentrations of Ag+ and Cl- ions are 0.02 M and 0.01 M, respectively. When 0.1 M NaCl is added, the concentration of Cl- ions will increase by 0.1 M, making the new concentration 0.11 M. Let x be the change in the concentration of Ag+ ions due to the shift in equilibrium:

(0.02 - x)(0.11) = 1.8 x 10^-10

Solving for x:

x ≈ 1.64 x 10^-9 M

The new concentration of Ag+ ions at equilibrium will be:

0.02 M - 1.64 x 10^-9 M ≈ 0.02 M

The addition of 0.1 M NaCl has a negligible effect on the concentration of Ag+ ions due to the very low solubility of AgCl. However, the equilibrium position has shifted to the left, favoring the formation of AgCl (s) and reducing the concentration of Ag+ ions in the solution.
